children.subject: Lakshya speaking fax as always

It must have taken courage to speak out, and I respect that!

But your insecurities have nothing to do with my post. 

I openly said in the title that it is unpaid.
Do you have any internships yourself - paid or otherwise?
I got my first job by contributing to an open source. 
If you have no skills in a certain area that you want to improve on - it takes employers resources and paid time of engineers to teach you instead of building our product.
This post is not for you,  Lakshya, but for people who are interested. 
I did not write with an intention to ruin your day, and you seem to have taken it personally, causing stress to both of us. What a waste of our time. 
It’s not my job to save the world. I am doing the best that I CAN to bring positive change to lives of a couple people.
At the moment we have 6 applicants. So your opinion is on a spectrum. 
Have a wonderful day whatever your beliefs are!

I had internships when I was a student, and they were paid. I'm fortunate enough to have graduated and be working full-time now, but many others depend on internship income to pay the bills and the tuition. I wouldn't say you've "ruined my day" in the slightest, and nor have I taken your post personally, although you seem to be rather offended by it. But I will address some of the things you've said.

"If you have zero skills - it takes employers RESOURCES and paid time of expensive engineers to teach you."

Using this as logic to not pay your interns is a load of malarkey, to put it politely. They still contribute to the project, at the end of the day, and the initial investment you place into them is (hopefully) outweighed by the benefit that they bring to the company overall in terms of fostering a young and steady pipeline of software engineers. And I'd hate to think you're hiring people with "zero skills", considering they're Berkeley Computer Science students. Internships help them grow, for sure, and interns require a degree of investment, but they also contribute to the culture and the productivity of the company and the overall software engineer ecosystem. It's not just a one-way street with benefit for the employee and none for the employer.

If anyone wants to work an unpaid internship, by all means, go for it. If you believe the experience is worth it, there really is nothing wrong with doing so. But there is something wrong with you, as an employer, phrasing your post as one in which you are doing a favor to students hurt by the awful job market. Experience doesn't pay the bills or put food on the table, and saying you're doing everyone a "favor" by getting free labor from students who have "zero skills" doesn't seem to be the best way to recruit, honestly. My issue isn't so much with recruiting for part-time unpaid internships (though I don't believe they should be a thing, honestly), but rather with the overall phrasing of employers doing "zero skill" software interns a favor by getting free labor out of them. Many will respond to your opportunity because of the sheer lack of options, but I do hope you, as a company, view them as better than how these posts imply you do.

Also, my name is spelled Lakshya.
nice

You have zero problem paying for your education at Berkeley. This internship’s purpose is not to resolve poverty, but to teach people who want to learn. I truly believe it’s an amazing opportunity because I know how the program is structured. I believe it’s invaluable for anyone who wants to become a better, more resilient engineer and ultimately have a happier life. And am doing it with only good intentions.

Why bully a small startup online?
A lot of our students were previously in clubs that didn’t do much for them. They wisely choose to put their time to build skills and a more impressive resume.

I just want to jump in and say that I worked with Lakshya back when we were both GSIs at Cal, and that he's one of the most dedicated and helpful people that I've ever met. While he was the head TA for CS 186, he often dedicated more than 30-40 hours a week helping answer questions on Piazza and guiding other students through concepts during office hours. There's a reason why he won the Outstanding Graduate Student Award two years in a row at Berkeley, and I dare say he's done an extraordinary amount to help other students here at this university.
That warmed my heart

Daniel, sounds like she volunteers her time for free to do something she likes and thinks is important. I just disagreed with her opinion. I don’t know what kind of person she is. And have no desire to fight with either of you, because no one was being attacked, to begin with. Except her saying I'm a bad person for trying to do what I can and trying something nice for others.

Also I just wanna add Anastasia edited her comments and this post to make it come off a little less aggressive than it initially was...

It doesn’t show up in the post history but I’ve been following this post on my phone for the lols
I edited those words because they don't reflect my beliefs, not to win an argument or conceal anything.
I edited those words because they don't reflect my beliefs, not to win an argument or conceal anything.
Are all interview slots filled up? Just saw that it was the contents of the notes were deleted :(
I got discouraged from offering this internship because of the negative feedback.

"You have zero problem paying for your education at Berkeley. This internship’s purpose is not to resolve poverty, but to teach people who want to learn. [...] A lot of our students were previously in clubs that didn’t do much for them. They wisely choose to put their time to build skills and a more impressive resume."

Hi Anastasia, I was actually paid for TA'ing and had health insurance through it as well. I enjoyed doing what I did, but I could never have done it if I wasn't paid for it somewhat, and if I wasn't given fee remission and compensation for my work, I daresay my family would be in a significantly worse financial spot right now. And a lot of interns are in the same position -- they need the experience that an internship provides, but they also need the funds.

If you can't pay your interns because of a lack of funding, fine, but please don't go inventing reasons like a "lack of experience" and "zero skill" for it. I'm not saying it would contribute zero value to their resume -- it will certainly add a bit if they do something meaningful. But you get just as much as they do, especially if you're a small startup, and it's good to acknowledge that.

At no point my post said I was not valuing the students. You are putting words into my mouth and mindreading.

It was in the spirit of collaboration, with stock options, paid courses we buy for our students, etc. 

I was trully trying to do something good for the world. And I've been shut down I guess. 

Now nobody benefits from nothing.

So you could probably have stated that there were stock options involved and other forms of compensation. I'm not trying to shut you down, but I am asking that you have a bit more respect for students. Your rhetoric throughout the post clearly showed you justifying unpaid internships as something where students were receiving far more than they were contributing, and it was quite clearly framed as something that does students a favor in this tight job market.

That's what I took issue with, and that's what I've been trying to say this entire time. A simple "yeah, I get it, and that wasn't our intention -- here is how we are offering compensation and this is how the internship would work; sorry if the initial phrasing came across like that" would probably have gotten you farther than any Piazza argument would have.

You are right. Youtubers deal with hateful comments all the time. I should have just ignored your post because you misread it. 

It was focusing on the positives because I was happy and inspired to help others. The whole point was to make internships less stressful and more valuable for career strategizing.

If you are triggered and feel attacked by reading an internship post - that's not my doing. You are choosing to react this way and waste your time on an argument.

I learned from this experience that I need a publicist to advise me to not engage in situations like these, because you are not focused on the argument itself. You are not trying to understand that both sides are imperfect or to develop some compassion. Like you said, you were only trying express your bad feelings. Even in my very first reply I satred with saying I respect and appreciate you speaking up. You only continued to pour dirt all over me. Not really reading what I mean, but looking for key phrases to "take issue with"

lmao any publicist worth their salt would've told you that most of your audience here recognizes unpaid internship opportunities as exploitative rather than benevolent. don't use hurt feelings to hide the fact that you're trying to take advantage of folks on this board
Rather than hire a publicist, maybe you should put that money towards paying your interns ¯\_(ツ)_/¯
I meant if I can afford it one day. But again, it's all just cherry-picking at my words. I should really shut up at this point, haha
Noone is cherry picking anything, don't kid yourself

Anastasia, I'm quite shocked by the rudeness of your responses. Lakshya simply shared his observation that your post came across as trying to take advantage of students during a difficult time. As you are an advocate for student empowerment, I'm sure you sympathize with his concerns, so I'm confused as to why you chose to attack his character and paint yourself as the victim.
I guess you're right, I could've spoken more softly. But I do believe in what I said. I'm only human and I make mistakes like everybody else. We both did not handle that interaction very gracefully
I regret at how this turned out

I've dealt with a lot of depression and health issues while at Cal, because I didn't know how to handle it. The tools I learned - both software and emotional intelligence and resilience really helped me turn my life around, get a good job, get a little less anxious and more happy. This internship was aimed to help people like me, struggling to keep up with the pressures of life. I truly had zero intention to take advantage of anybody. This was an idea that is not worth pursuing. But I'm not an evil person to the deepest core just because my idea was underdeveloped. I could've learned it just as well with lack of engagement on my post. But I will surely survive a couple anonymous jabs. :)

.

> graduates
> still checks eecs piazza
lakshya plz :" ), how can we help your spirit pass on to the after (grad) life
lakshya out here looking out for students from beyond the grave graduation

According to all known laws of aviation, there is no way that a bee should be able to fly. Its wings are too small to get its fat little body off the ground. The bee, of course, flies anyway. Because bees don’t care what humans think is impossible.” SEQ. 75 - “INTRO TO BARRY” INT. BENSON HOUSE - DAY ANGLE ON: Sneakers on the ground. Camera PANS UP to reveal BARRY BENSON’S BEDROOM ANGLE ON: Barry’s hand flipping through different sweaters in his closet. BARRY Yellow black, yellow black, yellow black, yellow black, yellow black, yellow black...oohh, black and yellow... ANGLE ON: Barry wearing the sweater he picked, looking in the mirror. BARRY (CONT’D) Yeah, let’s shake it up a little. He picks the black and yellow one. He then goes to the sink, takes the top off a CONTAINER OF HONEY, and puts some honey into his hair. He squirts some in his mouth and gargles. Then he takes the lid off the bottle, and rolls some on like deodorant. CUT TO: INT. BENSON HOUSE KITCHEN - CONTINUOUS Barry’s mother, JANET BENSON, yells up at Barry. JANET BENSON Barry, breakfast is ready! CUT TO: "Bee Movie" - JS REVISIONS 8/13/07 1. INT. BARRY’S ROOM - CONTINUOUS BARRY Coming! SFX: Phone RINGING. Barry’s antennae vibrate as they RING like a phone. Barry’s hands are wet. He looks around for a towel. BARRY (CONT’D) Hang on a second! He wipes his hands on his sweater, and pulls his antennae down to his ear and mouth. BARRY (CONT'D) Hello? His best friend, ADAM FLAYMAN, is on the other end. ADAM Barry? BARRY Adam? ADAM Can you believe this is happening? BARRY Can’t believe it. I’ll pick you up. Barry sticks his stinger in a sharpener. SFX: BUZZING AS HIS STINGER IS SHARPENED. He tests the sharpness with his finger. SFX: Bing. BARRY (CONT’D) Looking sharp. ANGLE ON: Barry hovering down the hall, sliding down the staircase bannister. Barry’s mother, JANET BENSON, is in the kitchen. JANET BENSON Barry, why don’t you use the stairs? Your father paid good money for those. "Bee Movie" - JS REVISIONS 8/13/07 2. BARRY Sorry, I’m excited. Barry’s father, MARTIN BENSON, ENTERS. He’s reading a NEWSPAPER with the HEADLINE, “Queen gives birth to thousandtuplets: Resting Comfortably.” MARTIN BENSON Here’s the graduate. We’re very proud of you, Son. And a perfect report card, all B’s. JANET BENSON (mushing Barry’s hair) Very proud. BARRY Ma! I’ve got a thing going here. Barry re-adjusts his hair, starts to leave. JANET BENSON You’ve got some lint on your fuzz. She picks it off. BARRY Ow, that’s me! MARTIN BENSON Wave to us. We’ll be in row 118,000. Barry zips off. BARRY Bye! JANET BENSON Barry, I told you, stop flying in the house! CUT TO: SEQ. 750 - DRIVING TO GRADUATION EXT. BEE SUBURB - MORNING A GARAGE DOOR OPENS. Barry drives out in his CAR. "Bee Movie" - JS REVISIONS 8/13/07 3. ANGLE ON: Barry’s friend, ADAM FLAYMAN, standing by the curb. He’s reading a NEWSPAPER with the HEADLINE: “Frisbee Hits Hive: Internet Down. Bee-stander: “I heard a sound, and next thing I knew...wham-o!.” Barry drives up, stops in front of Adam. Adam jumps in. BARRY Hey, Adam. ADAM Hey, Barry. (pointing at Barry’s hair) Is that fuzz gel? BARRY A little. It’s a special day. Finally graduating. ADAM I never thought I’d make it. BARRY Yeah, three days of grade school, three days of high school. ADAM Those were so awkward. BARRY Three days of college. I’m glad I took off one day in the middle and just hitchhiked around the hive. ADAM You did come back different. They drive by a bee who’s jogging. ARTIE Hi Barry! BARRY (to a bee pedestrian) Hey Artie, growing a mustache? Looks good. Barry and Adam drive from the suburbs into the city. ADAM Hey, did you hear about Frankie? "Bee Movie" - JS REVISIONS 8/13/07 4. BARRY Yeah. ADAM You going to his funeral? BARRY No, I’m not going to his funeral. Everybody knows you sting someone you die, you don’t waste it on a squirrel. He was such a hot head. ADAM Yeah, I guess he could’ve just gotten out of the way. The DRIVE through a loop de loop. BARRY AND ADAM Whoa...Whooo...wheee!! ADAM I love this incorporating the amusement park right into our regular day. BARRY I guess that’s why they say we don’t need vacations. CUT TO: SEQ. 95 - GRADUATION EXT. GRADUATION CEREMONY - CONTINUOUS Barry and Adam come to a stop. They exit the car, and fly over the crowd to their seats. * BARRY * (re: graduation ceremony) * Boy, quite a bit of pomp...under * the circumstances. * They land in their seats. BARRY (CONT’D) Well Adam, today we are men. "Bee Movie" - JS REVISIONS 8/13/07 5. ADAM We are. BARRY Bee-men. ADAM Amen! BARRY Hallelujah. Barry hits Adam’s forehead. Adam goes into the rapture. An announcement comes over the PA. ANNOUNCER (V.O) Students, faculty, distinguished bees...please welcome, Dean Buzzwell. ANGLE ON: DEAN BUZZWELL steps up to the podium. The podium has a sign that reads: “Welcome Graduating Class of:”, with train-station style flipping numbers after it. BUZZWELL Welcome New Hive City graduating class of... The numbers on the podium change to 9:15. BUZZWELL (CONT’D) ...9:15. (he clears his throat) And that concludes our graduation ceremonies. And begins your career at Honex Industries. BARRY Are we going to pick our job today? ADAM I heard it’s just orientation. The rows of chairs change in transformer-like mechanical motion to Universal Studios type tour trams. Buzzwell walks off stage. BARRY (re: trams) Whoa, heads up! Here we go. "Bee Movie" - JS REVISIONS 8/13/07 6. SEQ. 125 - “FACTORY” FEMALE VOICE (V.O) Keep your hands and antennas inside the tram at all times. (in Spanish) Dejen las manos y antennas adentro del tram a todos tiempos. BARRY I wonder what it’s going to be like? ADAM A little scary. Barry shakes Adam. BARRY AND ADAM AAHHHH! The tram passes under SIGNS READING: “Honex: A Division of Honesco: A Part of the Hexagon Group.” TRUDY Welcome to Honex, a division of Honesco, and a part of the Hexagon group. BARRY This is it! The Honex doors OPEN, revealing the factory. BARRY (CONT’D) Wow. TRUDY We know that you, as a bee, have worked your whole life to get to the point where you can work for your whole life. Honey begins when our valiant pollen jocks bring the nectar to the hive where our top secret formula is automatically color-corrected, scent adjusted and bubble contoured into this... Trudy GRABS a TEST TUBE OF HONEY from a technician. "Bee Movie" - JS REVISIONS 8/13/07 7. TRUDY (CONT’D) ...soothing, sweet syrup with its distinctive golden glow, you all know as... EVERYONE ON THE TRAM (in unison) H-o-n-e-y. Trudy flips the flask into the crowd, and laughs as they all scramble for it. ANGLE ON: A GIRL BEE catching the honey. ADAM (sotto) That girl was hot. BARRY (sotto) She’s my cousin. ADAM She is? BARRY Yes, we’re all cousins. ADAM Right. You’re right. TRUDY At Honex, we also constantly strive to improve every aspect of bee existence. These bees are stress testing a new helmet technology. ANGLE ON: A STUNT BEE in a HELMET getting hit with a NEWSPAPER, then a SHOE, then a FLYSWATTER. He gets up, and gives a “thumb’s up”. The graduate bees APPLAUD. ADAM (re: stunt bee) What do you think he makes? BARRY Not enough. TRUDY And here we have our latest advancement, the Krelman. "Bee Movie" - JS REVISIONS 8/13/07 8. BARRY Wow, what does that do? TRUDY Catches that little strand of honey that hangs after you pour it. Saves us millions. ANGLE ON: The Krelman machine. Bees with hand-shaped hats on, rotating around a wheel to catch drips of honey. Adam’s hand shoots up. ADAM Can anyone work on the Krelman? TRUDY Of course. Most bee jobs are small ones. But bees know that every small job, if it’s done well, means a lot. There are over 3000 different bee occupations. But choose carefully, because you’ll stay in the job that you pick for the rest of your life. The bees CHEER. ANGLE ON: Barry’s smile dropping slightly. BARRY The same job for the rest of your life? I didn’t know that. ADAM What’s the difference? TRUDY And you’ll be happy to know that bees as a species haven’t had one day off in 27 million years. BARRY So you’ll just work us to death? TRUDY (laughing) We’ll sure try. Everyone LAUGHS except Barry. "Bee Movie" - JS REVISIONS 8/13/07 9. The tram drops down a log-flume type steep drop. Cameras flash, as all the bees throw up their hands. The frame freezes into a snapshot. Barry looks concerned. The tram continues through 2 doors. FORM DISSOLVE TO: SEQ. 175 - “WALKING THE HIVE” INT. HONEX LOBBY ANGLE ON: The log-flume photo, as Barry looks at it. ADAM Wow. That blew my mind. BARRY (annoyed) “What’s the difference?” Adam, how could you say that? One job forever? That’s an insane choice to have to make. ADAM Well, I’m relieved. Now we only have to make one decision in life. BARRY But Adam, how could they never have told us that? ADAM Barry, why would you question anything? We’re bees. We’re the most perfectly functioning society on Earth. They walk by a newspaper stand with A SANDWICH BOARD READING: “Bee Goes Berserk: Stings Seven Then Self.” ANGLE ON: A BEE filling his car’s gas tank from a honey pump. He fills his car some, then takes a swig for himself. NEWSPAPER BEE (to the bee guzzling gas) Hey! Barry and Adam begin to cross the street. "Bee Movie" - JS REVISIONS 8/13/07 10. BARRY Yeah but Adam, did you ever think that maybe things work a little too well around here? They stop in the middle of the street. The traffic moves perfectly around them. ADAM Like what? Give me one example. BARRY (thinks) ...I

I don’t know. But you know what I’m talking about. They walk off. SEQ. 400 - “MEET THE JOCKS” SFX: The SOUND of Pollen Jocks. PAN DOWN from the Honex statue. J-GATE ANNOUNCER Please clear the gate. Royal Nectar Force on approach. Royal Nectar Force on approach. BARRY Wait a second. Check it out. Hey, hey, those are Pollen jocks. ADAM Wow. FOUR PATROL BEES FLY in through the hive’s giant Gothic entrance. The Patrol Bees are wearing fighter pilot helmets with black visors. ADAM (CONT’D) I’ve never seen them this close. BARRY They know what it’s like to go outside the hive. ADAM Yeah, but some of them don’t come back. "Bee Movie" - JS REVISIONS 8/13/07 11. The nectar from the pollen jocks is removed from their backpacks, and loaded into trucks on their way to Honex. A SMALL CROWD forms around the Patrol Bees. Each one has a PIT CREW that takes their nectar. Lou Loduca hurries a pit crew along: LOU LODUCA You guys did great! You’re monsters. You’re sky freaks! I love it! I love it! SCHOOL GIRLS are jumping up and down and squealing nearby. BARRY I wonder where those guys have just been? ADAM I don’t know. BARRY Their day’s not planned. Outside the hive, flying who-knows-where, doing who-knows-what. ADAM You can’t just decide one day to be a Pollen Jock. You have to be bred for that. BARRY Right. Pollen Jocks cross in close proximity to Barry and Adam. Some pollen falls off, onto Barry and Adam. BARRY (CONT’D) Look at that. That’s more pollen than you and I will ever see in a lifetime. ADAM (playing with the pollen) It’s just a status symbol. I think bees make too big a deal out of it. BARRY Perhaps, unless you’re wearing it, and the ladies see you wearing it. ANGLE ON: Two girl bees. "Bee Movie" - JS REVISIONS 8/13/07 12. ADAM Those ladies? Aren’t they our cousins too? BARRY Distant, distant. ANGLE ON: TWO POLLEN JOCKS. JACKSON Look at these two. SPLITZ Couple of Hive Harrys. JACKSON Let’s have some fun with them. The pollen jocks approach. Barry and Adam continue to talk to the girls. GIRL 1 It must be so dangerous being a pollen jock. BARRY Oh yeah, one time a bear had me pinned up against a mushroom. He had one paw on my throat, and with the other he was slapping me back and forth across the face. GIRL 1 Oh my. BARRY I never thought I’d knock him out. GIRL 2 (to Adam) And what were you doing during all of this? ADAM Obviously I was trying to alert the authorities. The girl swipes some pollen off of Adam with a finger. BARRY (re: pollen) I can autograph that if you want. "Bee Movie" - JS REVISIONS 8/13/07 13. JACKSON Little gusty out there today, wasn’t it, comrades? BARRY Yeah. Gusty. BUZZ You know, we’re going to hit a sunflower patch about six miles from here tomorrow. BARRY Six miles, huh? ADAM (whispering) Barry. BUZZ It’s a puddle-jump for us. But maybe you’re not up for it. BARRY Maybe I am. ADAM (whispering louder) You are not! BUZZ We’re going, oh-nine hundred at JGate. ADAM (re: j-gate) Whoa. BUZZ (leaning in, on top of Barry) What do you think, Buzzy Boy? Are you bee enough? BARRY I might be. It all depends on what oh-nine hundred means. CUT TO: SEQ. 450 - “THE BALCONY” "Bee Movie" - JS REVISIONS 8/13/07 14. INT. BENSON HOUSE BALCONY - LATER Barry is standing on the balcony alone, looking out over the city. Martin Benson ENTERS, sneaks up behind Barry and gooses him in his ribs. MARTIN BENSON Honex! BARRY Oh, Dad. You surprised me. MARTIN BENSON (laughing) Have you decided what you’re interested in, Son? BARRY Well, there’s a lot of choices. MARTIN BENSON But you only get one. Martin LAUGHS. BARRY Dad, do you ever get bored doing the same job every day? MARTIN BENSON Son, let me tell you something about stirring. (making the stirring motion) You grab that stick and you just move it around, and you stir it around. You get yourself into a rhythm, it’s a beautiful thing. BARRY You know dad, the more I think about it, maybe the honey field just isn’t right for me. MARTIN BENSON And you were thinking of what, making balloon animals? That’s a bad job for a guy with a stinger. "Bee Movie" - JS REVISIONS 8/13/07 15. BARRY Well no... MARTIN BENSON Janet, your son’s not sure he wants to go into honey. JANET BENSON Oh Barry, you are so funny sometimes. BARRY I’m not trying to be funny. MARTIN BENSON You’re not funny, you’re going into honey. Our son, the stirrer. JANET BENSON You’re going to be a stirrer?! BARRY No one’s listening to me. MARTIN BENSON Wait until you see the sticks I have for you. BARRY I can say anything I want right now. I’m going to get an ant tattoo. JANET BENSON Let’s open some fresh honey and celebrate. BARRY Maybe I’ll pierce my thorax! MARTIN BENSON (toasting) To honey! BARRY Shave my antennae! JANET BENSON To honey! "Bee Movie" - JS REVISIONS 8/13/07 16. BARRY Shack up with a grasshopper, get a gold tooth, and start calling everybody “Dawg.” CUT TO: SEQ. 760 - “JOB PLACEMENT” EXT. HONEX LOBBY - CONTINUOUS ANGLE ON: A BEE BUS STOP. One group of bees stands on the pavement, as another group hovers above them. A doubledecker bus pulls up. The hovering bees get on the top level, and the standing bees get on the bottom. Barry and Adam pull up outside of Honex. ADAM I can’t believe we’re starting work today. BARRY Today’s the day. Adam jumps out of the car. ADAM (O.C) Come on. All the good jobs will be gone. BARRY Yeah, right... ANGLE ON: A BOARD READING: “JOB PLACEMENT BOARD”. Buzzwell, the Bee Processor, is at the counter. Another BEE APPLICANT, SANDY SHRIMPKIN is EXITING. SANDY SHRIMPKIN Is it still available? BUZZWELL Hang on. (he looks at changing numbers on the board) Two left. And...one of them’s yours. Congratulations Son, step to the side please. "Bee Movie" - JS REVISIONS 8/13/07 17. SANDY SHRIMPKIN Yeah! ADAM (to Sandy, leaving) What did you get? SANDY SHRIMPKIN Picking the crud out. That is stellar! ADAM Wow. BUZZWELL (to Adam and Barry) Couple of newbies? ADAM Yes Sir. Our first day. We are ready. BUZZWELL Well, step up and make your choice. ANGLE ON: A CHART listing the different sectors of Honex. Heating, Cooling, Viscosity, Krelman, Pollen Counting, Stunt Bee, Pouring, Stirrer, Humming, Regurgitating, Front Desk, Hair Removal, Inspector No. 7, Chef, Lint Coordinator, Stripe Supervisor, Antennae-ball polisher, Mite Wrangler, Swatting Counselor, Wax Monkey, Wing Brusher, Hive Keeper, Restroom Attendant. ADAM (to Barry) You want to go first? BARRY No, you go. ADAM Oh my. What’s available? BUZZWELL Restroom attendant is always open, and not for the reason you think. ADAM Any chance of getting on to the Krelman, Sir? BUZZWELL Sure, you’re on. "Bee Movie" - JS REVISIONS 8/13/07 18. He plops the KRELMAN HAT onto Adam’s head. ANGLE ON: The job board. THE COLUMNS READ: “OCCUPATION” “POSITIONS AVAILABLE”, and “STATUS”. The middle column has numbers, and the right column has job openings flipping between “open”, “pending”, and “closed”. BUZZWELL (CONT’D) Oh, I’m sorry. The Krelman just closed out. ADAM Oh! He takes the hat off Adam. BUZZWELL Wax Monkey’s always open. The Krelman goes from “Closed” to “Open”. BUZZWELL (CONT’D) And the Krelman just opened up again. ADAM What happened? BUZZWELL Well, whenever a bee dies, that’s an opening. (pointing at the board) See that? He’s dead, dead, another dead one, deady, deadified, two more dead. Dead from the neck up, dead from the neck down. But, that’s life. ANGLE ON: Barry’s disturbed expression. ADAM (feeling pressure to decide) Oh, this is so hard. Heating, cooling, stunt bee, pourer, stirrer, humming, inspector no. 7, lint coordinator, stripe supervisor, antenna-ball polisher, mite wrangler-- Barry, Barry, what do you think I should-- Barry? Barry? "Bee Movie" - JS REVISIONS 8/13/07 19. Barry is gone. CUT TO: SEQ. 775 - “LOU LODUCA SPEECH” EXT. J-GATE - SAME TIME Splitz, Jackson, Buzz, Lou and two other BEES are going through final pre-flight checks. Barry ENTERS. LOU LODUCA Alright, we’ve got the sunflower patch in quadrant nine. Geranium window box on Sutton Place... Barry’s antennae rings, like a phone. ADAM (V.O) What happened to you? Where are you? Barry whispers throughout. BARRY I’m going out. ADAM (V.O) Out? Out where? BARRY Out there. ADAM (V.O) (putting it together) Oh no. BARRY I have to, before I go to work for the rest of my life. ADAM (V.O) You’re going to die! You’re crazy! Hello? BARRY Oh, another call coming in. "Bee Movie" - JS REVISIONS 8/13/07 20. ADAM (V.O) You’re cra-- Barry HANGS UP. ANGLE ON: Lou Loduca. LOU LODUCA If anyone’s feeling brave, there’s a Korean Deli on 83rd that gets their roses today. BARRY (timidly) Hey guys. BUZZ Well, look at that. SPLITZ Isn’t that the kid we saw yesterday? LOU LODUCA (to Barry) Hold it son, flight deck’s restricted. JACKSON It’s okay Lou, we’re going to take him up. Splitz and Jackson CHUCKLE. LOU LODUCA Really? Feeling lucky, are ya? A YOUNGER SMALLER BEE THAN BARRY, CHET, runs up with a release waiver for Barry to sign. CHET Sign here. Here. Just initial that. Thank you. LOU LODUCA Okay, you got a rain advisory today and as you all know, bees cannot fly in rain. So be careful. As always, (reading off clipboard) watch your brooms, hockey sticks, dogs, birds, bears, and bats. "Bee Movie" - JS REVISIONS 8/13/07 21. Also, I got a couple reports of root beer being poured on us. Murphy’s in a home because of it, just babbling like a cicada. BARRY That’s awful. LOU LODUCA And a reminder for all you rookies, bee law nu

Hi Anastasia, I haven't responded to you primarily because I don't quite feel comfortable opining on something like stock options, as I don't know the legal implications of such an idea and whether that would be (legally) sufficient for compensation.

It's great that you are thinking of ways to compensate interns; I know nothing about your startup, so I just hope that you continue to explore ways to properly compensate them -- ideally with financial compensation instead of stock options, but certainly with something instead of nothing.

My point was simple: that interns should be paid if at all possible, and that they should be treated with respect in discourse regardless. I hope this point was made clear in our conversation on this forum.
lol, it's all good, man :)

I hope I made it clear that I am a worker not in charge of these decisions. What can I do about it? Handshake is full of unpaid positions. I've being told at Berkeley career center that it's a good idea for ME to take an unpaid internship. And I have in the past.

Some people don't have a chance to get any degree, and learning with real instructors is beneficial for many people who don't feel comfortable going on their own. The program was designed to be 2 months of learning with certificates the company was going to pay for and with a job interview at the end.

But you only wanted to attack someone and be angry. You made me think my life was over for a bit there. 

When you make a mistake you want other people to excuse you, look away, and forgive. 

I would never erupt on a grocery store clerk working minimum wage for having only plastic bags in the store because it's 1. out of their control and 2. they are a human being and deserve compassion. 

I'm not at all saying that I'm perfect. But I believe this was not constructive dialog.

I work for minimum wage with a Berkeley CS degree. What was I supposed to do instead of doing my job?

And my comment wasn't about you at all. It was a general comment. 

More than 400 people saw this thread. So many comments are attacks. 

Not a single person gave feedback on me trying to make this a positive outcome and do something good. 

I am not trying to victimize myself. I am also not trying to change your mind.

I really mean it's all good. I understand your point of view.
or it might turn out ok, and he won't respond at all because it doesn't matter much :)

"Because we live in an “employer’s market”, jobs are more scarce than the amount of talented people who can do those jobs very well.I want to challenge that and teach the future generation of world-changers and creatives."

Okay, I understand that this is a part-time gig, and I know many startups are also short on funding right now, but I still don't think that's a good reason to basically phrase an "unpaid internship" as a wonderful opportunity that does students a favor, as this post seems to imply.

I wish I could pay everybody, even provide universal income for the entire world. But I don't have that kind of money. How am I supposed to do it then when you can hire full-on engineers who need zero guidance and directly solve our problems for a fraction of the cost it takes to manage interns. Berkeley students are very smart and deserve to get paid for learning. Maybe in the future the company will be able to afford that. But not at the moment

"Berkeley students are very smart and deserve to get paid for learning."

yeah they are. why don't you pay them? especially when plenty of other opportunities are paying them? you said it yourself, so are you sure you're looking for interns in the right place?

That's what I'm thinking now. We had very positive response on LinkedIn from less impressive schools and people who may not have a chance to go to college. But Berkeley students seem like they don't really need this kind of opportunity because they are at a more advanced stage already
It's quite disappointing that the lesson you learned from this little social media adventure is that it's easier to exploit students from schools with fewer resources.

You don't know what I learned from this. It will take me a couple days to process the situation. I really do want to make a positive difference with the little limited resources that I have. I'm not at all planning to "exploit" anyone. People around the world have all kinds of different lives and values. And if both sides are happy with the value they retrieve - that's positive to me. Why are you assuming that people are too stupid to know what's best for them? If some are interested - that's their choice. But I'm not even sure I want to deal with interns anymore, we have Entry Level paid roles as well. So the resources allocated for interns could get diverted to benefit our new hires instead, focusing on the quality instead of size of the team. But idk, I'm allowed to change my mind. All I know is that I will try to make it a good thing for somebody to benefit from.
*woops wrong followup

Note that in the United States, unpaid internships are dubiously legal. See https://www.dol.gov/agencies/whd/fact-sheets/71-flsa-internships

Many parts of this "internship" would involve the intern doing real work for your company, or at least you say it does, which would likely entail those interns to minimum wage.
oh boy
now i'm being trolled too. that backfired

<md>This is a great opportunity! To the haters, I have to ask, what do you have against the free market 🦅🇺🇲? The free market gives and the free market takes away, but more importantly, the free market is perfect!!! If companies with lots of VC funding don't want to pay interns, that's their business, and especially in a pandemic, people don't need wages 🚫💲! Come on, do we want to live in some kind of socialist hellhole with some kind of "minimum wage"? No, we love the free market!! Long live Ayn Rand 🧠🧠 and long live America 🦅🦅🇺🇲🇺🇲.</md>
good point. I will think it through and grow from this experience.
good to hear. you're helping out a lot of students and will help out even more if there is at least some form of compensation
^ if anyone thinks this is just OP pretending to be someone else smash the helpful button on this post
No. This is Anastasia posting anonymously
my anonymous nickname is Anonymous gear. I did not pretend anything. You really see the worst in people
Andrew, you seem to like adding fire and encouraging the drama
E X P O S E D
i think the "she" in that screenshot is intended to be lakshya lol
sorry, i didn't realize it's a he till now

I think you were quite aggressive throughout this whole fiasco, but I do believe you're trying to help. I think the points made by others (other than the troll) are valid, so it would be wonderful if you reposted the opportunity but also gave something more immediately beneficial as well.

I am just an employee - I don't make financial decisions. All I can do is go back to my boss and say a bunch of guys got angry so I failed at the task he gave me.

Edit: turns out international students may be able to legally do paid internships.

As an international student, thats actually a false claim. International students can do a paid internship under the CPT visa process which can be added onto the F1 visa (despite different restrictions). Myself and a lot of my other international friends have interned at Apple, Facebook, Nvidia, etc. where they get paid equally as an in-state intern.

Not starting an argument here but to get facts straight because this is an actual question and concern international students have -- international students can 100% do a paid internship based on F-1 visa restrictions. In fact, it can even be riskier if you are unpaid. 

For internships, you'd often use what's called a CPT authorization - and there is an entire class of CPT authorization called "paid CPT", which you can receive by submitting your job offer to the folks at Berkeley International Office. 

I've been through it and I was paid three summers, and I was also paid as a TA and course staff from Berkeley, so international students can definitely be paid.
^ Yes. I was also paid as a reader/TA at Berkeley. What Brian says is a lot more detailed and accurate.

That's super helpful to know, thank you. I learned about it on Stanford's website. I was an F-1 student and was told it was impossible. It's awesome that it is possible after all. And i think I will have to talk to my boss and ask not do hire interns. But ultimately that's not my decision.
i can vouch for the effectiveness of rootlynk's product, in the span of hours just mentioning it has managed to bring 3 graduated TAs back to life imagine what it can do for your plants
I'm so behind on 161

It was a super tough class for me too! Just stick with it and remember that your success in the class is not tied to your value as a human being. Life is too short to be scared of bad grades instead of enjoying learning.
@Anon calc My email and Nick's email are always open if you need extensions/accommodations or just want to vent
Yay, that's warms my heart :)
lmao

history.content:
I have an idea! I'll talk to the founders and ask if we can give stock options to the interns. 

That would mean it will no longer be learning-only internship- they will have to split their time between the mentorship program, getting certifications, and more menial tasks that are essential to the company's growth (sun) :) 

And even if we can't do it as a company, I can dilute my stocks if it means building a team of amazing co-workers, engineers, and friends

What do you guys think? =)

history.subject: Internship Ideation

history.content:
Hi friends,

As a recent graduate I remember too well the difficulty of finding a role where you feel like you are making a positive difference, where an employer doesn’t want 5 years of experience, where you feel engaged, and learn and make projects that directly contribute to your career aspirations?

Because we live in an “employer’s market”, jobs are more scarce than the amount of talented people who can do those jobs very well.I want to challenge that and teach the future generation of world-changers and creatives. 

RootLynk is a startup that seeks to develop IoT soil moisture, temperature, and light sensors to help plant owners keep their plants in good health. RootLynk will be able to utilize multiple units to collect key data, allowing the user to plan for growth and care of plants. Our main goal in this internship is to make sure you learn and grow as an engineer while also being a valuable team member. 🤗 The way we do it:

1. Initial interview to see what your skills, interests, and aspirations are. Here I will see if you are a good fit.
2. Collaborative Interview where we'll plan how your interests can be fitted towards current or future RootLynk's projects.
3. Depending on the type of internship, you may have one last interview with one of the cofounders.

* International students are eligible!
* Optional course credit, flexible schedule, fully remote
* Customized to your learning needs

Have questions? Comment on here, email or connect with me on LinkedIn -  Anastasia Sukhorebraya-Beck

If you're interested in applying, grab some time for our initial interview here

Cheers,

Anastasia Sukhorebraya-Beck

Senior Software Engineer, RootLynk
history.subject: Software Engineering Internship (remote, unpaid, part-time)
